post.author: Mogsy @ BiblioSanctum
post.title: Friday Face-Off: An Aerial Encounter
post.text:
Welcome to The Friday Face-Off, a weekly meme created by Books by Proxy! Each Friday, we will pit cover against cover while also taking the opportunity to showcase gorgeous artwork and feature some of our favorite book covers. If you want to join the fun, simply choose a book each Friday that fits that week’s predetermined theme, post and compare two or more different covers available for that book, then name your favorite. A list of future weeks’ themes are available at Lynn’s Book Blog. 
This week’s theme is: 
~ a cover featuring AN AERIAL ENCOUNTER 
Mogsy’s Pick:
Skyward by Brandon Sanderson
Skyward by Brandon Sanderson, a book that is all about aerial encounters. In Spensa’s world, everyone has heard of the heroic achievements of the Defiant Defense Force in the Battle of Alta—the battle in which forty pilots protected their planet Detritus from the alien Krell attack. Except in Spensa’s case, her father was known as the pilot who ran, shot down in disgrace for trying to abandon the fight. Now Spensa lives with the stain of that disgrace, but being a pilot has always been her greatest desire. Despite efforts to keep her out, she manages to make it into Flight School, more determined than ever to be come a full-fledged pilot for the DDF even with the deck stacked against her. 
Given the story and its themes, I’m actually surprised there aren’t more covers for this book featuring aerial encounters, but I did find some. Let’s take a look at this week’s competition: 
From left to right: 
Delacrote Press (2018) – Gollancz (2018) 
  
Polish Edition (2019) – Bulgarian Edition (2019) – Turkish Edition (2020) 
   
Italian Edition (2019) – Russian Edition (2020) 
  
German Edition (2021) – French Edition (2020) – Estonian Edition (2020) 
   
Winner
I’ve always love the cover to the UK (Gollancz) edition of this book, and while there were a bunch of new ones here I hadn’t seen before, nothing quite came close to unseating it. 
But what do you think? Which one is your favorite?

post.title: Speculative Fiction Links of the Week for January 15, 2021
post.text: It's  time for the latest weekly round-up of interesting  links  about speculative   fiction from  around the web, this week with the best science fiction and fantasy of 2020 and the decade, a look ahead at 2021, season 3 of Star Trek Discovery and Star Trek in general, The Mandalorian and Star Wars in general, season 5 of The Expanse, Wonder Woman 1984, WandaVision, season 3 of American Gods, Outside the Wire, Robert E. Howard's Bran Mak Morn and much  more.  Speculative fiction in general:Nick Petrie shares nine great science fiction thrillers.  James Davis Nicoll shares five of the best SFF books he never meant to read. Natalie Zutter shares seven SFF stories that grew beyond their original worldbuilding. James Davis Nicoll shares five science fiction novels featuring space travel powered by atomic bombs.  Joyce Reynolds-Ward wonders whether SFF writer romanticising revolutions may have played a part in inspiring the storming of the Capitol on January 6, 2021. Alex Acks lists six black indie SFF writers to read.  Kritika Agrawal shares sevem surprising facts about Octavia E. Butler.  Rachel Hawkins takes a look at the many retellings of Jane Eyre.  Bill Ward shares his appreciation for the Bran Mak Morn stories by Robert E. Howard. Jason Ray Carney points out that Bran Mak Morn might be considered a social justice warrior.  Doug Ellis reports about the Edgar Rice Burroughs revival of the 1960s.Jason Powell offers an overview of George R.R. Martin's Wild Cards series. Jeff Noon explains how he came from writing science fiction to writing crime fiction.   Brian Murphy shares his appreciation for the artwork of Boris Vallejo.  Dangerous Minds remembers cover artist Bob Haberfield. Julie Hinds reports about the forgotten black artists of the early comics industry. Sian Cain reports that the cover for the Tintin album The Blue Lotus from 1936 has been sold for a record-breaking 3.2 million Euro. Sian Cain reports that Neal Kirby, son of Captain America co-creator Jack Kirby, is furious that some of the far right protesters who stormed the Capitol used Captain America imagery.  Sarah Parvini reports that virtual Dungeons & Dragons games are booming during the pandemic.  Alison Flood reports that the UK Royal Mint's H.G. Wells commemorative coin not only features a tripod with four legs, but also a wrong quote. Kristie Lim reports that a rare second edition of the classic gothic novel The Mysteries of Udolpho by Ann Radcliffe has been discovered in a library in Perth, Australia.   Adam Whitehead reports that Ty Frank and Daniel Abraham a.k.a. James S.A. Corey have ruled out that they will complete George R.R. Martin's A Song of Ice and Fire. Adam Whitehead reports that David Weber, who contracted covid, has been released from hospital and is on the mend.   Best of 2020 and the decade: Mark Yon shares his favourite SFF books of the decade.  Kat G. shares her favourite SFF books of the decade. Mark Chitty shares his favourite SFF books of the decade.Shellie Horst shares her favourite SFF books of the decade.Rob Bedford shares his favourite SFF books of the decade. Joachim Boaz shares his favourite SFF books he read in 2020.  A look ahead at 2021:  Liz Bourke shares her most anticipated books of 2021.  Leah Schnelbach shares the most anticipated science fiction and fantasy books of 2021. Joe Sherry shares 21 science fiction and fantasy books he's looking forward to in 2021. Gwilym Mumford takes a look ahead at the TV series coming out in 2021.    Film and TV: Jack Seale calls season 2 of A Discovery of Witches a bloodlessbore featuring vanilla vampires. Cath Clarke calls The Intergalactic Adventures of Max Cloud virtually pointless. Leslie Felperin calls Hunted a nifty and nasty Red Riding Hood retelling.Cath Clarke shares her thoughts on the science fiction movie Archive. Kayla Kumari Upadhyaya shares her thoughts on the latest episode of The Stand.  Vikram Murthi shares his thoughts on the latest episode of Disenchantment.   Andrea Johnson revisits the 1964 science fiction movie Robinson Crusoe on Mars. Jessica Holmes revisits the 1965/66 Doctor Who serial "The Daleks' Master Plan". Kris Vyas-Myall revisits the 1966 horror movies Dracula: Prince of Darkness and Plague of the Zombies.  Peter Bradshaw revisits the 1983 horror movie Grizzly II: Revenge and finds it unbearable, in spite of a very young George Clooney and Laura Dern starring. Ralph Jones shares an oral history of the 1996 time travel movie Twelve Monkeys and interviews director Terry Gilliam as well as several crewmembers. Tom Breihan revisits the 2002 Spider-Man movie.Leyla Yvonne Ergil talks about the legacy of Turkish science fiction and superhero movies.George Bass interviews Franka Potente and Moritz Bleibtreu, the stars of the 1998 alternate reality crime movie Run, Lola, Run.  Mitchell W. Maknis profiles voice actors David Sobolov and Ryan Colt Levy.  Liz Shannon Miller reports that the Martian Manhunter was hiding in plain sight in Man of Steel and Batman versus Superman: Dawn of Justice all along, played by actor Harry Lennix.  Natalie Zutter has some questions regarding the Disney+ adaptation of The Thief by Megan Whalen-Turner.Molly Templeton shares some casting news for season 3 of The Umbrella Academy.Germain Lussier shares some updates about the Marvel Cinematic and TV Universe. The BBC reports that a young Doctor Who fan from Saxmundham, UK, had been given a custom TARDIS doorframe by his parents.  Arnold Schwarzenegger has a message for Donald Trump and all Americans and brandishes Conan's sword to reinforce it.Horror and action movie actress Julie Strain has died aged 58.  Comments on season 3 of Star Trek Discovery and Star Trek in general:Keith R.A. Ben Child reports that director Patty Jenkins did not have to deal with much studio interferences, while making Wonder Woman 1984. Mike Sampson reports that Warner Bros has launched a campaign to get Wonder Woman 1984 nominated for the Academy Award for Best Picture.  Comments on WandaVision: Sam Barsanti declares that WandaVision unleashed the untapped weird power of the Marvel Cinematic and TV Universe. Stuart Heritage interviews Kevin Feige, producer of WandaVision and Elizabeth Olsen and Paul Bettany, who play Wanda Maximoff a.k.a. Nominations for the 2021 FAAn Awards are open. The recipients of the 2020 Horror Writers Association's diversity grants have been announced. The winners of the 2021 Helicon Awards have been announced. The organisers of the Arthur C. Jonathan Strahan reports that Ian Whates will be taking over the editorship of Interzone. post.author: Lady S
post.title: Reading Wrap-up: 2020 Edition
post.text:
Hey there! Welcome to a brand new year, and my very first post of 2021. I can’t believe it’s already mid January, time really does fly. Today, I’ll be sharing my completed reading list for 2020. It wasn’t the best of reading years for me, but it wasn’t the worst either. When I compiled my list I realized I’d actually read more than I thought, and even surpassed the previous year’s record, (by the skin of my teeth). I tried to include a wider variety of genres, but of course, fantasy and sci-fi won out for the most reads. I had pretty good luck with the non-fiction reads I chose, but as for fiction, most of the books I read weren’t great. With the exception of a few, it seemed like most of the novels I picked up last year were just average, and didn’t capture my attention. Which led me to feel very uninspired about my TBR. But looking back, it turned out to be a rather decent reading year, despite my lack of enthusiasm. 



Now let’s get to the list: 







Ratings: 1-5  



Favorites in bold 



Non-Fiction 



The Universe Next Door, by James W. Sire – 4Beyond Brilliance, by Lucas Miller – 4Writing Your Story’s Theme, by K.M. Weiland – 5Reversing Hermon, by Dr. Michael S. Heiser – 5True Legends, by Steven Quayle  – 5Herbal Home Healthcare, by John R. Christopher – 5



Sci-fi/Fantasy 



Fireborn, by Rosaria Munda – 4Beyond the Deep Woods: The Edge Chronicles 1, by Paul Stewart and Chris Riddell – 5The Christ Virus, by Dave Slade – 3Starsight, by Brandon Sanderson – 4Into the Fire, by Kim Vandel (re-read) – 5Among the Flames, by Kim Vandel (re-read) – 5A Time to Die, by Nadine Brandes – 3The Scorpio Races, by Maggie Stiefvater – 5The Malamander, by Thomas Taylor – 2On The Edge of the Dark Sea of Darkness, the Wingfeather Saga book 1, by Andrew Peterson – 4To Sleep in a Sea of Stars, by Christopher Paolini – 3The Dark Hills Divide, The Land of Elyon book 1, by Patrick Carman – 4The Lost Colony, Artemis Fowl book 5, by Eoin Colfer – 4Paranormia, by Paul Regnier – 5



Classics 



The Moonstone, by Wilkie Collins – 4The Eagle of the Ninth, by Rosemary Sutcliff – 4 The Scarlet Pimpernel, by Baroness Orczy – 5



Contemporary/Historical 



The Heart of a Samurai, by Margi Pruess – 5The Scent of Water, by Elizabeth Goudge – 5Rose Cottage, by A.K. Madison – 4The Penderwicks book 1, by Jeanne Birdsall – 5A Monster Calls, by Patrick Ness – 4



Total : 28 







Top 4 Mini-Reviews: 



Beyond The Deep Woods, by Paul Stewart & Chris Riddell 



In this story, we follow a misfit boy who was raised by an adoptive family in the Deep Woods; a dark and dangerous place filled with all sorts of strange, and ferocious beasts. He sets out all alone on a journey through the wilds, and has many curious encounters with some very odd characters. This is a Middle-Grade book, but it can be read and enjoyed by anyone looking for an adventure. The storyline was very original, and I was surprised to find out that it was not a modern publication, but was published over twenty years ago.  



The Scorpio Races, by Maggie Steifvater 



Taking place on the small, windswept, isle of Thisby, we follow Puck Connolly, and Sean Kendrick as they prepare for The Scorpio Races. A yearly event where racers compete for a grand prize—and sometimes to the death—atop the violent, and wild, water horses called, capaill uisce. This book had me staying up late into the night, and reading for hours to reach the end. I actually found this book at a thrift store a few years ago, and left it sitting untouched on my bookshelf for so long! I’m happy that I finally got around to reading it. I loved everything about this book, and I think it’s my favorite book of the entire year. 



Paranormia, by Paul Regnier 



Chris Loury is young, broke, and kind of a nerd. Struggling to find his way in life, and hoping to land a contract for his original comic, he ends up in a strange accident. After that fateful night, he is swept into a series of wild encounters, and has several run-ins with a lunatic who claims to be an angel. But as events unfold, and Chris finds himself digging deeper into trouble, he starts to believe the lunatic is actually who–or rather what he says he is. I appreciated the way the supernatural elements were handled in this story, and I thought Chris was a very relatable character, especially to all of my fellow twenty-something’s out there, who are trying to make their own way in the world. Overall, a solid read. 



The Scent of Water, by Elizabeth Goudge 



The perfect, cozy British tale to curl up with under a blanket, and a cup of tea. This story centers around Mary, a woman who retires to a small English village, and becomes acquainted with the inhabitants there. Learning to love the quiet of the countryside, Mary also finds herself becoming involved in the many joys, and heartaches with her new neighbors. This was one of the few books I was actually sad to finish. I’ll likely be reading more books, by Miss Goudge in the future. 







Most Disappointing: 



Unpopular opinion here: I was actually very disappointed in, A Time to Die, by Nadine Brandes. I’d read so many great reviews of this book, (and I enjoyed her other books,) but after reading, A Time to Die I don’t really get the hype. For starters, it felt sort of like two books squashed into one, with so much going on. I never connected with the main character, Parvin, and I thought it a little unrealistic how much trauma she went through, and still survived. (Though that was kind of the point of the story.) In general, there were many aspects of the story that I found very unrealistic, and slightly annoying. I wanted to like this book, but I just couldn’t, and as of right now I don’t think I’ll continue with the series.  



To Sleep in a Sea of Stars, by Christopher Paolini 



Firstly, I loved the cover, and this title is exactly what I like to see from sci-fi novels. I was a big fan of the Inheritance Cycle, by Paolini, but unfortunately I didn’t love this book. This is not a YA book, nor does it pretend to be, but I felt like I went into it a little blind. Especially for younger Paolini fans, I’d warn them about the amount of profanity, and adult themes throughout. It was an interesting story, and read like any space epic, but, I didn’t find it out of this world fantastic. Die-hard sci-fi fans would probably enjoy this book, but I’m not adding it to my favorites list. Also, it’s nearly 900 hundred pages, so beware. 







Thus concludes my list, and a few reviews, for all the books I cracked open during the year 2020. I may have forgotten a few, since I didn’t keep track very well. There were also a few DNF’s (Did Not Finish), throughout the year which I didn’t list here, but that’s for the best. This year I’m hoping to read more, since I feel like I’m finally in a good reading mood, but then again I say that every year, and things don’t always pan out. I would like to continue to expand genres, and read more non-fiction. And in general, just read outside of my comfort zone, because I feel a bit like I’ve read those genres dry, and I know I’ll find some new, unexpected favorites, if I’d only look to new avenues. 







What about you? How many books did you read in 2020? What was your favorite read of the year? Leave me a comment, and let me know! 



 



Thanks for reading, 



Lady S

post.author: Greg
post.title: 14 Jan 2021 – Brandon Sanderson, “The Way of Kings”
post.text: Epic fantasy is epic. Read as a free ebook from Tor, all two thousand smartphone pages of it, on trams, trains, and toilets. Thinking that I might have to read the sequels (which, let’s face it, probably, at some point, sure) makes my head spin a little. AND this is still ongoing. Christ on a bike. Still, can you even be into fantasy and never read a Sanderson? Probably, but I’m one cat who’ll definitely die to curiosity some day.

bridgefourisgayrights: if-one-of-us-falls: 

bridgefourisgayrights: moash: 

moash: moash: moash: 

do we think whatever blinded moash that couldn’t be healed was physical or spiritual? do his eyes look different, considering how important eye color is to him/society? speaking of eyes, did bonding the honorblade give him lighteyes again? i mean it does right?   


i have more thoughts about this but i need to get my phd in investiture before i elaborate, remind me to comment on this in three years  
ok so i do want to learn more about investiture before i commit to this line of reasoning, but thoughts on this theory: there’s nothing special about the wound itself, he’s just subconsciously not healing his eyes, the way kaladin subconsciously didn’t heal his scars like first, moash is a character that’s literally just a bunch of parallels to kaladin in a trenchcoat. like he exists to be a dark mirror to kaladin. second, kaladin didn’t heal his scars with stormlight bc subconsciously they were representative of his past that he couldn’t let go of. he’s able to heal them when he’s started to take steps towards setting down that burden and healing. for moash to suffer a wound he can’t heal from in the same battle? parallels. moash was sitting w his feelings for a while before the singers found him and his whole problem is he doesn’t want to think about the things he’s done, he doesn’t want to look at his past. kaladin couldn’t set his pain down, moash can’t bear to look at his.  the reason i want to know more about investiture before i commit to this is that i can’t think of, based on my limited knowledge, a reason why he couldn’t heal from this. storm/voidlight have so far healed every single non fatal wound, even shardblade wounds that sever the soul from the body. maybe a reason exists, but i don’t know enough to say, and i probably favor this kind of theory bc i’m fond of moash as a character. hit me w ur thoughts  
like not for nothing, but moash also didn’t heal his bridge four tattoo, which we know is possible bc kaladin healed his tattoos (granted, very soon after he got them). moash instead wears shirts w sleeves that cover it, when he could just heal it. sub con scious !  


So I’m a thousand years late to this but anyway you’re absolutely onto something. I have a minor in Investiture and I hope I can explain just how right you are. Healing in the Cosmere works through an aspect of Investiture called Identity. Identity is the individual self, the self as differentiated from others, and all the things that come with that: personality, lowercase i identity, etc. Identity, for example, is why Feruchemists on Scadrial can’t use another Feruchemist’s metalmind. It’s why Awakeners on Nalthis can put their Breath in objects but another Awakener can’t take it out—like, for example, say Kaladin somehow knew Awakener commands, he couldn’t have got breaths from the pieces of cloth Zahel Awakened. However, if Zahel *did* give his Breath to Kaladin, the Breaths would take on Kaladin’s identity, and be his. A more relevant example is the Singers’ slaveform: the binding of Ba-Ado-Mishram stole their Identity, which is why none of them remember life before enslavement. That Bondsmith fundamentally found a way to *steal their very selves*, which is why the Radiants went “Oh no we’re the bad guys.” Healing is a connection (lowercase c) between a person’s Spiritual (ideal, or true, self) self and their Physical self, filtered through their self perception, or their Cognitive self. This is why Lopen could heal an old injury, but Kaladin couldn’t heal his scars. Sanderson does a good job saying that the ideal self isn’t necessary the *best* or *optimal* self: the implication across the Cosmere is that *nobody knows what lies beyond the Spiritual Realm. A person is free to define themselves however they want without some big spiritual entity saying they have to be someone, while still following hard magic system rules. An important line I found fact checking is that “even if a wound is recent, if thr person has changed their mindset to see it as part of themselves, they will not be able to heal from it.” Stormlight can heal Shardblade wounds because healing comes from the Spiritual self, or where the soul fundamentally is. There are a thousand different theories on what the hell was going on with Renarin’s image, but we all agree the mystery is around Moash—it definitely wasn’t Renarin’s perception of him. I honestly wasn’t thinking and assumed it was some kind of Magic Wound™, BUT, if it wasn’t healed, it would absolutely imply something about the way he sees himself. I’ve also wondered if it’s not just a coping mechanism, but like… my words have run out but like a way to sort of put him out of the fight. Maybe parallels to Jezrien, who went blind despite the Herald’s healing because of his guilt for abandoning humanity (I don’t think he’ll end up like that, but another example of that happening). I hope that makes sense!! I just love this character too and I wanted to say how right you were. 
@bridgefourisgayrights thanks for the detailed Identity explanation, I’ve been trying to wrap my brain around it!  I definitely agree with this line of reasoning. I also love how well the parallels to Kaladin line up.  I want to bring up an additional detail - the cause of that wound. Specifically Towerlight.   Earlier in Navani’s POV, we saw Moash freeze in place when Navani sang the anti-Voidlight tone. This is understandable because it probably cut off/ weakened his Connection to Odium. (On a sidenote, I wonder if in that moment he experienced what Kaladin experiences when he freezes). Later, though, when the Towerlight hits him, he runs away. Again his Connection to Odium is severed (because the tower’s protections have been fixed) and it takes him a few paragraphs to realize that he’s been blinded. Honestly I’m not even sure of the exact moment he has been blinded because his narrative is so frenzied and unclear at this point. My guess is that it’s right when he exits the tower, when the light catches up to him and “burns” him. Anyway he runs away, same as after Renarin’s illusion, which makes me think even more that Renarin used something other than Stormlight. I also just remembered that in the clinic, Teft describes Moash as being in shadow despite the room’s many spheres. I wonder if it’s just a thematic choice or something more tangible. It’s a bit of a stretch but it reminds me a little of the palace in Kholinar being constantly in shadow because of the influence of the Unmade. I think it was Ashertmarn who caused it but it could be Yelig-Nar. 


Ooo very interesting addition! I also realized that Honorblades can’t heal Shardblade wounds. I wonder if that means the Towerlight damage, like you said, is somehow linked to his Connection to Odium, and is deeper than Physical Realm damage. Not really plot relevant—unless it leads to a plot where fully breaking from Odium or maybe bonding with a true spren will heal him, if Sanderson goes there—but interesting Realmatically.

post.author: Eva
post.title: Aleación de ley - Brandon Sanderson (Mistborn 04)
post.text: Sinopsis Han pasado ya trescientos años desde los acontecimientos narrados en la trilogía Nacidos de la Bruma (Mistborn) y Scadrial se encuentra ahora cerca de la modernidad: ferrocarriles, canales, iluminación eléctrica y los primeros rascacielos invaden el planeta. Aunque la ciencia y la tecnología están alcanzando nuevos retos, la antigua magia de la alomancia continúa desempeñando un papel fundamental. En una zona conocida como los Áridos existen herramientas cruciales para aquellos hombres y mujeres que intentan establecer el orden y la justicia. Uno de estos hombres es Lord Waxillium Ladrian, experto en metales y en el uso de la alomancia y la feruquimia. Después de vivir veinte años en los Áridos, Wax se ha visto obligado, por una tragedia familiar, a volver a la metrópolis de Elendel. Sin embargo, y a su pesar, deberá guardar las armas y asumir las obligaciones que exige el hecho de estar rodeado de la clase noble. O al menos eso cree, ya que aún no sabe que las mansiones y las elegantes calles arboladas de la ciudad pueden ser incluso más peligrosas que las llanuras de los Áridos. Un skyline metálico de bruma, de ceniza y vapor conquista el cielo amenazando a todos aquellos que viven y luchan debajo de él.

post.author: katelynnon
post.title: Top 10: Lecturas de 2020
post.text:
¿Qué podemos decir de 2020 que no se haya dicho ya? Supongo que una de las opiniones más extendidas es «¡Menos mal que por fin se ha terminado!», pero… ¿hasta qué punto significa eso algo? ¿Acaso eso nos garantiza que se avecinen tiempos mejores? 



Aun así, la sensación de cambio y de empezar de cero que trae el nuevo año es innegable. Y siempre es más sano mantener un cierto optimismo y pensar que, con lo feo que fue el anterior, este no puede ser mucho peor. Aunque reconozco que yo no tengo tanto de lo que quejarme como otras personas. 



Volver la vista atrás siempre es una buena forma de cerrar un capítulo y dar la bienvenida al siguiente. Y, como no todo ha sido malo en 2020, es hora de dedicarle un pequeño espacio a una de las cosas buenas de este último año: mis lecturas favoritas. Me ha sido muy difícil establecer una verdadera clasificación y no acabo de estar segura al cien por cien de algunos puestos, pero me hacía ilusión dejaros un pequeño Top 10, como siempre de menos a más. 



Puesto 10: Nimona (Noelle Stevenson)







Por desgracia, no pude prestar tanta atención a esta novela gráfica como habría deseado, pues fue mi «libro de los fines de semana». Aclaración: vivo entre dos localidades y continuamente transporto ropa y otros utensilios entre una y otra, pero prefiero tener la mayoría de libros en el que considero mi verdadero hogar; por lo tanto, suelo llevarme un único libro a la otra casa y leerlo entre semana, mientras que los fines de semana, que tengo menos tiempo, cojo alguno de la estantería, normalmente colecciones de relatos o lecturas más pequeñas y ligeras. 



Después de esta desviación, vamos a lo interesante: mis impresiones de Nimona. Tenía muchas ganas de leer este libro porque lo había visto recomendado en varias ocasiones y porque la descripción prometía muchas de mis cosas favoritas: ¡dragones! ¡Archienemigos! ¡Cambiaformas! ¡Humor! En efecto, su protagonista es una joven con muchas ganas de hacer maldades y la habilidad de transformarse en toda clase de criaturas que comienza a trabajar como ayudante de un supervillano. Siempre me han llamado la atención las historias desde el punto de vista de los «malos» e incomprendidos y, como yo sospechaba, hay momentos en los que Lord Blackheart se acaba convirtiendo más bien en un héroe oscuro al que se le coge mucho cariño. También encontramos muchos momentos cómicos y alguna que otra relación con potencial de shippeo (once a fanficker, always a fanficker). Los dibujos y la fuente en la que están escritos los textos parecen mal hechos adrede, como si los hubiera pintado un niño, lo cual les da mucha simpatía. Sin ánimo de hacer spoilers, el final es algo triste o agridulce y quizás sea lo único que no me terminó de gustar, pues rompe con el tono juguetón y un tanto absurdo de la novela. 



Puesto 9: The Prince and the Dressmaker (Jen Wang)







De nuevo, una novela gráfica, pero muy distinta de la anterior. Entre las tres que escogí para explorar este género es la única que no contiene elementos de fantasía y, tal vez por eso, era la que menos me atraía. Me interesé por ella porque era una de las más recomendadas para un público joven —no sé si ya comenté que uno de los motivos por los que decidí dar una oportunidad a las novelas gráficas era para poder compartirlas con mis alumnes— y porque trataba temas sobre identidad de género. He de decir que me sorprendió muy gratamente. 



Estéticamente es una verdadera preciosidad a pesar de su aparente sencillez. Si te gusta ver vestidos bonitos y originales, te lo pasarás pipa con esta novela. La trama es muy tierna y esperanzadora, si bien tiene algo de drama: trata de una joven modista que ansía la fama entre la alta sociedad y un príncipe lleno de inseguridades que disfruta adoptando una identidad femenina. No termina de quedar claro si Sebastian, que así se llama, es una mujer trans o si fluctúa entre el género femenino y el masculino, pero eso es lo de menos. Lo mejor es la amistad entre sus protagonistas y, aunque tal vez la historia peque de demasiado optimista, de tanto en tanto necesitamos algo que nos deje con una sonrisa o alguna que otra lagrimilla de alegría. 



Puesto 8: Elantris (Brandon Sanderson)







Llevaba queriendo leer a Sanderson desde que lo conocí en el Celsius. Primero compré Alcatraz contra los bibliotecarios malvados, cuyo narrador me resultó muy simpático. Sin embargo, la historia no terminó de engancharme, así que decidí probar con algo más adulto. Elantris fue mi elección, pues muchas personas hablaban maravillas de esta novela y se me ocurrió que sería mejor iniciarse con un libro que no formase parte de una saga. Ah, y porque me gustaba cómo sonaba el título. 



Una de las cosas que me habían llamado la atención era que se tratase de una historia de fantasía sin viajes, en la que todo ocurre en un mismo lugar…, aunque ese lugar fuera una especie de prisión para zombis. Para mi gusto, es una novela muy larga y lenta, por lo que se me hizo algo cuesta arriba. ¿La parte buena? Sus tres protagonistas: un príncipe caído en desgracia que no pierde su optimismo y sus ganas de luchar, una princesa valiente y astuta y un fanático religioso que sufre una crisis de fe. Este último, además, tiene uno de esos arcos de personaje de los que a mí me gustan.   



Puesto 7: Sueño del Fevre (George R. R. Martin)







Martin no podía faltar en un top hecho por mí. De los tres libros suyos que he leído este año, Sueño del Fevre ha sido mi favorito, aunque en un empate muy reñido con algunos de los cuentos de Retratos de los hijos. Nunca me han atraído demasiado los vampiros pero, por mucho que sus lectores describan esta novela como «vampiros y barcos de vapor en el Mississippi», es mucho más que eso. Martin nos muestra la relación entre dos hombres que no podrían ser más diferentes, que empieza como una asociación puramente comercial y termina convirtiéndose en una gran amistad, y la lucha de un capitán de barco por cumplir sus sueños y restaurar su reputación. En ella encontramos muchas de las constantes de este autor: un protagonista feo y corpulento, misterio, escenas truculentas, gran presencia de la comida, damas de piel pálida, cabello oscuro y hechiceros ojos de color violeta… 



Puesto 6: Mala Hierba (Andrea Arroyo del Campo)







¿Ambientación de fantasía medieval? ¿Protagonistas femeninas que hacen cosas? ¿Intrigas políticas? ¿Cambios de bando? En cuanto coincidí con su Andrea en nuestra presentación conjunta, supe que tendría que leerlo. Y que me gustaría. No me decepcionó en absoluto. 



Anahí de Garland, una princesa heredera que se ve obligada a ejercer como brazo ejecutor de un tirano para poder salvar su vida, es una de las pocas protagonistas que me han conquistado desde las primeras páginas gracias a su humor, sus conflictos internos absolutamente realistas y su fortaleza. El que además hubiera representación LGBT+ y personas gato solo son añadidos. Aquí podéis ver lo que la propia autora nos cuenta sobre la que ha sido su primera novela. 



Menciones honorables



Este apartado es para algunas obras que se han quedado a las puertas de este ranking. Me avergüenza reconocer que, entre unas cosas y otras, casi está mi lista completa de lecturas de 2020 en esta entrada, pero ha habido un par de novelas que me han consumido demasiado tiempo y no me han permitido leer más. Sea como sea, estas son las candidatas.   



—Saga de las reinas de Fennbirn (Kendare Blake): como ya comenté, tuve demasiados altibajos con esta tetralogía como para incluirla entre mis favoritas. Eso sí, la mención honorable se la merece aunque sea solo por todo el tiempo que me ha acompañado y entretenido. 



—Baba Yaga’s Assistant (Marika McCoola): una novela gráfica muy simpática, pero tal vez demasiado corta. 



—Retratos de los hijos (George R. R. Martin): ya sabéis que no me gusta repetir autores. Además, así como algunos relatos me impactaron, otros pasaron sin pena ni gloria. 



Puesto 5: El corazón de Ixchel (Varias autoras)







Si el gran problema de las antologías unipersonales es que pueden resultar repetitivas debido a los «fetiches» de su autore, el de las antologías colectivas es que suelen tener muchos altibajos. No es el caso de El corazón de Ixchel. Prometo que no estoy haciendo la pelota a Ediciones Hati cuando digo que se merecen mi más sincera enhorabuena por la selección. 



El corazón de Ixchel me sorprendió gratamente porque, dentro de sus diferencias de estilo, todos los relatos presentan un gran nivel. Llegué a pensar que cada uno era aún mejor que el anterior. Tengo mis favoritos —aquí viene cuando hago sufrir a M. J. Ceruti una vez más al hablar de lo dolorosamente real que me resultó «Pish Taco» y cómo con unas pocas páginas comprendemos perfectamente las relaciones entre los miembros de una pequeña familia y la personalidad de cada uno— y, en cambio, solo recuerdo un cuento que no me gustó nada, pero creo que es porque su autora y yo simplemente no nos entendemos. 



Puesto 4: Saga de Kyoshi (F. C. Yee)







Cualquier cosa que me permita regresar al universo de Avatar siempre será bien recibida. Y más cuando se trata de uno de mis personajes secundarios favoritos: Avatar Kyoshi, la predecesora del Reino Tierra de Aang. En la serie me llamaba mucho la atención por su peculiar estética y porque presentaba una personalidad completamente contraria a la de Aang: seria, firme y dispuesta a ser despiadada cuando la situación lo requiere. 







Así que, cuando descubrí que existía una novela en dos partes centrada en sus orígenes, no pude resistirme. De modo similar a los arcos de redención, hay un cierto encanto en las historias en las que un personaje pasa de cero a héroe, como es el caso de nuestra protagonista: Kyoshi inicia su aventura como una huérfana hambrienta a la que rescatan de las calles para trabajar como sirvienta en la mansión del nuevo Avatar… hasta que se descubre que el verdadero Avatar es ella. A partir de ahí, somos testigos de su entrenamiento, sus peripecias con la banda de criminales a la que pertenecían sus padres, su primer amor, su trama de venganza contra el hombre que más daño causó a sus seres queridos e incluso sus primeras intervenciones como figura política. Y todo ello aderezado con batallas épicas de magia elemental, criaturas asombrosas y nuevos detalles acerca de ese mundo que quienes hemos visto la serie conocemos tan bien. 



Puesto 3: Momo (Michael Ende)



Uno de los pocos clásicos que, en mi opinión, de verdad merecen su estatus. Para ser una novela juvenil, la trama tarda un poco en despegar, pero se le perdona porque la presentación de los personajes es muy original y casi tan importante como la aventura que narra. Entre un sinfín de elementos fantásticos y pasajes cargados de poesía, Ende nos plantea una serie de reflexiones sobre la sociedad moderna y una crítica nada sutil al capitalismo, tan necesarias y relevantes hoy en día como en el año 1973, cuando se publicó por primera vez. 







Puesto 2: La canción secreta del mundo (José Antonio Cotrina)



Con la cantidad de veces que he nombrado este libro, voy a tener que empezar a pedir a Cotrina que me dé comisión. Así que, en vez de repetir lo que ya he dicho hasta la saciedad, os dejo con esta minireseña de mi sis literaria, a la que parece que le gustó tanto como a mí. 







Puesto 1: Asesino de brujas: la bruja blanca (Shelby Mahurin)







En Las lágrimas de los dioses, tenemos a un inquisidor y una bruja que se ven obligados a colaborar para salvar el mundo; aquí, tenemos a un cazador de brujas y a una bruja a los que circunstancias de la vida les obligan a… ¡casarse! Con una premisa así, no podía perdérmelo. Esta historia de amor envuelta en fantasía tiene una ambientación que nos recuerda a la Francia prerrevolucionaria, con su fastuosidad y algún que otro personaje histórico de incógnito. Si bien hay algunas fuerzas sobrenaturales que amenazan el reino, estas se mantienen ocultas y solo se manifiestan en algún que otro golpe menor hasta la segunda mitad de la novela, lo cual, lejos de restarle emoción, nos permite conocer mejor a sus dos protagonistas, que estos se conozcan mejor entre ellos y que el romance florezca a fuego lento. Otros puntos fuertes son los momentos de alivio cómico y su villana, tan carismática como temible.

post.author: Andreas Chari
post.title: Reading on the KULT 2021: Week 02
post.text:
Hello Kultists, let’s see how my reading went this week. 







Earlier this week I finished Look to Windward by Iain M. Banks. It was one of the pleasant reads of the Culture and even though not my personal favourite in series I believe it’s one of Banks’ best written ones. The worldbuilding as always was top notch and I loved the characters and the story. I also finished The Philosopher’s Toolkit: A Compendium of Philosophical Concepts and Methods by Julian Baggini & Peter S. Fosl. The book was pretty dense but it did cover a lot of tools and concepts that any philosophy enthusiast will find useful and insightful.  







Also, I started reading The Daily Stoic: 366 Meditations for Clarity, Effectiveness, and Serenity by Stephen Hanselman & Ryan Holiday, since I’ve been hearing a lot about it and some meditation guidance in the climate wouldn’t hurt at all. It will be a long read since you’re supposed to read one meditation per day so let’s hope I manage to do it consistently and not DNF it after a month. Speaking of DNFs, I started reading Brave New World by Aldous Huxley last weekend but after about a third way through I just couldn’t get through his writing, the story and premise were quite fascinating so I may try to listen to the audiobook sometime in the future. Lastly, I started reading The Gathering Storm by Brandon Sanderson & Robert Jordan. I’m currently more than halfway through it and Sanderson gave a new breath of life to the series. The story is coming to an end and we finally start to unravel the conclusion of Jordan’s epic series. 







That was my reading on week 02 of 2021. Let me know how you’re doing in the comments.

post.author: lloydearickson
post.title: Oathbringer Review
post.text: If you’ve been following along over the past few reviews, you probably won’t be surprised by another rave review for a Stormlight book.  To be honest, I probably have a somewhat unhealthy obsessions with these books.  There are plenty of books that I enjoy, and stories that I will happily reread and have a new experience with each time, but my experience with this series is on a different level.  Maybe it’s the philosophical questions it confronts, or maybe it’s the incredibly imaginative and vividly detailed world, or maybe it’s the compellingly flawed, fascinating, and terribly relatable characters.  Whatever the case, Oathbringer continues to be, to my mind, the gold standard for what epic fantasy ought to be.

post.author: Molly Templeton
post.title: A TV Adaptation of Brian McClellan’s Powder Mage Series Is in the Works
post.text:
Dark Matter creator Joseph Mallozzi has a new project: adaptating Brian McClellan’s Powder Mage books for television. Deadline reports that Mallozzi is set to write the pilot episode, “with a view to” showrunning the one-hour series. 
 
Mallozzi’s resume leans heavily toward science fiction; he executive produced and wrote for Stargate SG-1, Stargate: Atlantis, and Stargate Universe, created and wrote for the underrated Dark Matter, and is the showrunner for Utopia Falls. But Powder Mage takes him in a new direction—the series, which starts with McClellan’s debut novel, Promise of Blood, is set in a fantastical world where powder mages get their abilities from gunpowder. Reviewing the first book, Tor.com’s Stefan Raets said it “seems to be aimed straight at the same readers who enjoy Brandon Sanderson’s novels.” 
Here’s the publisher’s summary of the first book: 
Civil unrest cripples the citizens of Adro in the aftermath of the revolution that obliterated the monarchy. Now, Field Marshal Tamas and his lieutenants must confront the true cost of freedom in book one of the Powder Mage Trilogy. 
It’s a bloody business overthrowing a king. . . 
Field Marshal Tamas’ coup against his king sent corrupt aristocrats to the guillotine and brought bread to the starving. But it also provoked war with the Nine Nations, internal attacks by royalist fanatics, and the greedy to scramble for money and power by Tamas’s supposed allies: the Church, workers unions, and mercenary forces. 
It’s up to a few. . . 
Stretched to his limit, Tamas is relying heavily on his few remaining powder mages, including the embittered Taniel, a brilliant marksman who also happens to be his estranged son, and Adamat, a retired police inspector whose loyalty is being tested by blackmail. 
But when gods are involved. . . 
Now, as attacks batter them from within and without, the credulous are whispering about omens of death and destruction. Just old peasant legends about the gods waking to walk the earth. No modern educated man believes that sort of thing. But they should. . . 
There’s no news yet on production schedule, casting, or premiere date.

post.author: Caro @ bookcheshirecat
post.title: My 2021 Out of Your Comfort Zone Challenge TBR
post.text:
Hello fellow bookworms  I’ve already talked about what 2021 Reading Challenges I’m joining, but my very own reading challenge returns this year, so here I am posting my #outofcomfortzonechallenge TBR! Like last year I picked out 4 genres and one age range out of my comfort zone to read this year and I have dedicated 3 books per category to put on my TBR! This is less than last year, as I noticed that I didn’t read much of my set TBR as I mood read a lot more compared to previous years, and having too many books picked out beforehand became a source of stress. Therefore, I’m picking my Top 3 Priority Reads per category (still 15 books in total). These are books that I’m super excited for right now, though I might adjust my little TBR when my mood changes  I’m starting with a short reminder of what my challenge is all about and then it’s straight to my TBR!  
Thank you to everyone who already signed up  
➽ There’s still time to sign up all year, if you want to  If I missed your post somehow, feel free to link it down below, I love seeing what is on everyone’s TBR  

Becca @ ipreferthebook
Nikki @ nikkiswiftreads
Sabrina @ wordyandwhimsical
Sophie @ meandink
Tara @ thephantomreads

 
What is the Out of Your Comfort Zone Reading Challenge?  
The aim of this challenge is to read books that you consider to be outside of your comfort zone. The Challenge itself is tailored to your goals, so it’s going to be really relaxed and individual as everyone has a different definition of their comfort zone. You can set yourself a number of books to read in a particular genre (or subgenre, age range, etc.) or make a TBR with books you hope to get to! There are also fun levels and badges to collect if you’re interested in that! 
Get all the information in my announcement post  
I’d love for you to join me and chat about our progress throughout the year  
 

Signup Form
Form for adding your read books

 
My #outofcomfortzonechallenge TBR  
 
I read a lot more sci-fi books last year and rediscovered my love for the genre. Right now I’d love to escape into space, so I definitely want to keep reading books in this genre, especially as they have been so much fun!  I have two sequels to beloved books that I definitely want to read in 2021. I adored Skyward, so Starsight is on the top of my priority list and I can see myself reading this very soon  I also need to finally read Undying, as I read the first book such a long time ago, yet never picked up the sequel  Last but not least, I have been wanting to get my hands on Skyhunter, as I love Marie Lu and need to catch up with her new releases! 

Starsight (Brandon Sanderson)  Sequel to Skyward
Undying (Kaufman & Spooner)  Sequel to Unearthed
Skyhunter (Marie Lu) 

 
 
Sadly, I still haven’t been reading historical fiction as regularly last year, so I hope to try to read some books again this year! For me, reading historical fiction book with a fantasy element seems to have worked well, so I’m definitely making use of that. As I didn’t get to it in 2020, I will be reading The Dire King, the big finale of the Jackaby series, one of my favorite new series of all time  Apart from that I have been getting more into reading books inspired by the Arthurian legend, so I picked up The Guinevere Deception on ebook as it sounds just like what I’m in the mood for currently! I also want to read The Enigma Game, as I adore the series and I was so excited that we got a new companion book in 2020  

The Guinevere Deception (Kiersten White) 
The Enigma Game (Kaufman & Spooner)  Companion to Code Name Verity
The Dire King (William Ritter)  Finale of the Jackaby Series

 
 
Predictably, Mystery and Thriller were my least read genres for the challenge last year, as it’s still very much out of my comfort zone. However, I want to try to at least read some books in the genres: thriller, mystery or light horror. My top priority book is Dead Voices, a Middle Grade Horror/Mystery book and sequel to one of my surprise favorites of last year. I love how each book is themed around a different season, for this book it’s winter, so I might read it soon   Another author I discovered last year is Kate Alice Marshall (author of Rules for Vanishing) and I’m very excited for her 2021 release Our Last Echoes, it sounds amazing!! A 2020 release I need to get to is I Hope You’re Listening, as it’s a mystery involving a podcast element!  

Dead Voices (Katherine Arden)  Sequel to Small Spaces
Our Last Echoes (Kate Alice Marshall) 
I Hope You’re Listening (Tom Ryan) 

 
 
I read a bunch of nonfiction at the beginning of last year, but then it fizzled out towards the end of the year. I’m still happy that I read so many nonfiction books in 2020, as it used to be one genre I never considered for myself. In 2021 I don’t plan on reading as much nonfiction, but I still have some books I’d love to get to. I definitely want to educate myself better on racism, so I’m starting out with So You Want to Talk About Race, which I heard is the most accessible. However, I have more advanced books on my TBR as well. A book that also interests me and that I’ve heard good things about is All Boys Aren’t Blue, a collection of personal essays. Finally, I also plan on reading Body Talk, an anthology with an incredible 37 authors who talk about what living in their bodies is like. 

So You Want to Talk About Race (Ijeoma Oluo) 
All Boys Aren’t Blue (George M. Johnson) 
Body Talk (Anthology) 

 
 
I actually read some adult books last year, though it’s still not an age-range that I reach for often (it’s really intimidating, even with some great recommendations of the bookish community). I 100% want to read Network Effect as I fell in love with the Murderbot Diaries last year and this is the first full-length novel, as the previous books were all novellas. That makes me even more excited as we get more Murderbot content (and there’s another novella out in 2021)  I also fell in love with Matt Haig’s books in the past year and his new 2020 release sounded so good as The Midnight Library deals with multiple realities, which interests me. His books have convinced me in 2020, so I can’t wait to read this one!  Finally, I got the e-book of Get a Life, Chloe Brown, as everyone seems to have loved this romance book! Sadly, I didn’t like the author’s 2020 Christmas novella, but I hope her other books are good! 

Network Effect (Martha Wells)  Book 5 in the Murderbot Diaries
Get a Life, Chloe Brown (Talia Hibbert) 
The Midnight Library (Matt Haig) 

Are you planning on participating in the #outofcomfortzonechallenge? What are some books out of your comfort zone you’d like to read?

post.author: Sarah Yoo
post.title: How to Write a Romance Novel (& Publish)
post.text: Romance (including erotica) is the hottest genre to sell in, being the most profitable on Amazon by $1.44 billion. Since the pandemic, romance ebooks saw an extra 17% boost in the US:  Romance is a great space to be in for self-publishers, more so with its recent rebound. I quickly go over the trends below. Then, I break down how to get started with writing and eventually publishing your book.  Industry overview The myth about self-published books being priced at $2.99 or below? That’s now broken as reported by the self-publishing platform PublishDrive. In 2020, romance was its 2nd highest-priced category at around $7. The platform also saw crazy spikes in romance subcategories like a 2,728% increase in vampire and a 1,377% increase in new adult. Overall, indies made 69% more digital book sales in 2020 via PublishDrive. The growth was apparent across digital formats like audiobooks, models like subscription services, and channels like libraries. And 70% of the sales came from international markets. Going global, digitally, is the best move for romance indies right now.  <div style="text-align: center; CLICK FOR FREE REPORT ON GLOBAL BOOK TRENDS IN 2020 Tips on how to write a romance novelNow you know just how profitable this genre is. Whether you’re an avid romance reader wanting to transition into a writer or an experienced author looking for a refresher, let’s go over the basics for writing romance. First, read as many romance books as you can. Get specific with the subgenre, like vampire, contemporary, or historical romance. It’s important to get a good grasp on how your category is typically structured. Figuring out your subgenre also helps with launching your book later on (I go over this further down.) Don’t know where to start? Check out the works of these romance writers and see how it’s done: Jane Austen is a classic and celebrated romanticist who wrote about love, marriage, societal drama, and more. Start with Emma or Pride and Prejudice (you can watch the film too.)Nora Roberts is a New York Times bestselling author of over 215 novels. Standalone favorites include The Villa, Northern Lights, and The Collector.E L James’ Fifty Shades of Grey started off as a raunchy self-published book, quickly rising to fame as a cultural icon.R.R. Banks is one of PublishDrive’s bestselling contemporary romance authors, making a splash in the realm of audiobooks.Here’s a list of the best romance novels.A good romance novel should keep the reader glued until the end. Here are common tropes to know: The main characters have complementary personalities or reasons to click.The couple goes from friends to lovers or rivals to lovers.The story is plot-driven, with twists, turns, and conflicts. For example, forbidden love.The first meeting is memorable. Romantic comedy? Maybe an embarrassing one.The main characters can’t help but be in each other’s orbit, mainly due to external forces.There are fun interactions and banter.The lovers challenge each other (to be better humans) and share vulnerabilities.The breakup is dramatic and soul-crushing. ”This will never work out!”The character development arc includes sacrifices to get back together. Love over ego.Eventually, the story rushes to a big declaration of love and commitment.99% of the time, the lovers end up together happily ever after.Keep in mind that people reading romance stories usually do so for cliches and stereotypes. As successful romance writer Jane Eyre said, “there is no happiness like that of being loved by your fellow-creatures, and feeling that your presence is an addition to their comfort.” More recommendations for your writing process: Watch Brandon Sanderson’s free video courses for general writing advice. Here’s one where he covers romance.Read Writing a Romance Novel For Dummies or On Writing Romance.Join online writing communities to bounce off ideas, get feedback, and connect with others. Check out Reddit’s Writers’ Group, romance authors group, and Discord’s Writers Society.Practice with romance writing prompts.At the end of the day, pull inspiration from your real-life experiences and daydreams.  Tips on self-publishing romance novelsAfter completing your manuscript, it’s time to prepare for publication. Here’s what to expect: Editing – Hire a proofreader or find a beta reader.Cover design – This is a crucial marketing element for attracting attention. Look at PublishDrive’s bestselling romance book covers for inspiration. ↓ Layout formatting – Convert your manuscript file(s) for ebook, audio, or print-on-demand.Distribution – You can sell only on Amazon KDP (a common choice among indies), but you’ll miss out on billions of other readers. Instead, go wide by distributing everywhere via book aggregators like PublishDrive.Marketing – Grow your author brand and business with a solid marketing strategy.I suggest reading this guide which expands on every step of the publishing process.  PublishDrive helps prepare your manuscript for ebook, audio, and print conversion. It takes only a few clicks to distribute your book in stores like Amazon, Apple, and Google:   Publish In 4 Easy Steps Tip #1: When prepping your book, be sure to optimize metadata. This includes choosing the best (sub)categories, cover design, and adding the strongest hooks in the first two sentences of your blurb. Doing so helps your book rank higher in stores and engage the right audience.  Tip #2: Don’t just publish an ebook; expand your reach with audiobook and print-on-demand. The most successful indies on PublishDrive sell in all three formats to maximize their selling potential. On PublishDrive, you can publish and manage these different formats with a simple upload process. Tip #3: Distribute your book in multiple countries where the demand for English-language content is high. Go beyond Amazon, and distribute in multiple stores as well. Along with major retailers like Google Play Books, online libraries like Odilo are dominating in growth: <div style="text-align: center; CLICK FOR FREE REPORT ON GLOBAL BOOK TRENDS IN 2020 Tip #4: Try publishing a series, an effective way to build up author credibility and relevance in search results. Indies use this tactic to add more reads on platforms like KDP. By the way, a series doesn’t mean sequels. You can write three unrelated romance novels and package them together with a series name like “Romance to Read While Traveling.” Tip #5: Invest in your marketing, seriously. PublishDrive analyzed 800 price promos for online retail stores. These promos achieved 10x more sales and an additional 2% bump for non-promoted books. Tactics like discount campaigns, Facebook ads, Amazon ads, Bookbub ads, newsletter features, and social media swaps with published authors make up a powerful strategy. Promotions help attract readers to your book. Then, items like your cover design, title, blurb, and reviews help convert to sales.  Absorb everything you can on writing and creating a romance book. Afterward, treat self-publishing as a business (going global and digital is key!) In an environment like the pandemic, we see why the demand for love stories has gone up. In the words of bestselling romance author Gena Showalter, “I went online and ordered every romance novel I could find. They're fairy tales for grown-ups.” ❤️  When you’re ready, sell and promote in thousands of stores worldwide with PublishDrive. Publish easily in no time:   Start Free 14-Day Trial  PublishDrive in action. ↓

post.title: BABY CHALLENGE 2021 - FANTASY
post.text: Je me lance dans le Baby Challenge cette année, option "Fantasy" bien entendu ! Alors, j'ai mis en GRAS tout ce que je possède déjà, physique et Ebook avec le tome correspondant à mon niveau de lecture dans la saga. En ROUGE, ceux que je ne lirais pas, car je ne suis pas fan du tout.Et tout le reste, c'est "dans ma Wish List", dirons nous ^^  Si certaines personnes souhaites faire des lectures communes, n'hésitez pas, je suis partante !  BABY CHALLENGE 2021 - FANTASY1.    Univers - Le Royaume des Anciens*, de Robin Hobb : T1 (l'assassin royal)2.    Saga - Les archives de Roshar, de Brandon Sanderson : T13.    Le Seigneur des Anneaux, de J. R. R. Tolkien4.    Saga - Martyrs, d'Olivier Peru : T15.    Saga - Kushiel, de Jacqueline Carey T16.    Saga - Fils-des-brumes, de Brandon Sanderson : T17.    Les âmes croisées, de Pierre Bottero : T18.    Saga - Chronique du tueur de roi, de Patrick Rothfuss9.     Saga - Le Trône de Fer, de George R. R. Martin10.    Les Illusions de Sav-Loar, de Manon Fargetton11.    Saga - Rozenn, de Laëtitia Danae12.    Saga - Récits du vieux royaume, de Jean-Philippe Jaworski13.    Saga - Le puits des mémoires, de Gabriel Katz : T114.    Saga - Les Salauds Gentilshommes, de Scott Lynch : T115.    Saga - Prince captif, de C. S. Pacat16.    Saga - Le cycle des démons, de Peter V. Brett : T117.    Saga - Les bannis et les proscrits, de James Clemens : T118.    Saga - Les Portes du secret, de Maria V. Snyder19.    Saga - L'Ange de la nuit, de Brent Weeks : T220.    Elantris, de Brandon Sanderson   Jokers :   1.    Les Garennes de Watership Down / Watership Down, de Richard Adams2.    Saga - Troie, de David Gemmell3.    Circé, de Madeline Miller4.    Saga - Les Annales du Disque-Monde, de Terry Pratchett5.    Saga - Warbreaker, de Brandon Sanderson* Univers Le Royaume des Anciens : Saga L'Assassin royal + Saga Les Aventuriers de la Mer + Saga Les Cités des Anciens + Saga Le fou et l'assassin
